text: in the fight against terrorism the most
valuable sources of intelligence are
agents who risk their lives by going
undercover
their stories are rarely told in public
this man uses the name Amon Dean it's
not his real one that's because he
risked his life infiltrating al-qaeda
for British intelligence if you want to
catch rats you know you will have to go
into the civil and get dirty born in
Saudi Arabia he went to Afghanistan in
the 90s where he swore an oath of
loyalty to Osama bin Laden
but the increasing focus on killing
civilians led to disillusionment
he began informing not just in
Afghanistan but also in Britain even at
one point attending the same meeting as
three of the men who carried out the
July 7th bombings there were few
occasions where lives were saved and
plots were interrupted but I would
rather keep that to myself
Britain's Intelligence Service mi6 has a
policy of neither confirming nor denying
the identities of its agents but the BBC
has been able to corroborate key
elements of Ayman Dean's story he feels
he has a duty to speak out now because
of the way young Muslims are being drawn
to Syria and Iraq after controversy in
the last week over attempts to recruit
the man known as jihadi John Dean says
that the best agents are those not
recruited because of pressure but
because of their conscience it's a
choice he says he does not regret gordon
carrera BBC news
